evidenceItems.title: Brief, calm scripts during child distress
evidenceItems.claim: Short, consistent language with calm caregiver affect supports de-escalation better than extended verbal negotiation under stress.

sourceRefs.citation: Sege RD, Siegel BS. Effective Discipline to Raise Healthy Children. Pediatrics. 2018;142(6):e20183112.

evidenceItems.title: Consistent caregiver response
evidenceItems.claim: Consistent response patterns are associated with better behavioral adjustment than variable responses.

sourceRefs.citation: Cochrane Review. Group-based parent training programmes for improving emotional and behavioural adjustment in young children. CD003680.

evidenceItems.title: Safety-first intervention for aggression/unsafe behavior
evidenceItems.claim: Immediate safety actions (blocking danger, removing hazards) should precede coaching language during high-risk moments.

sourceRefs.citation: Sege RD, Siegel BS. Effective Discipline to Raise Healthy Children. Pediatrics. 2018;142(6):e20183112.

evidenceItems.title: Parent skills training improves child behavior
evidenceItems.claim: Behavioral parent training is effective for reducing disruptive behavior patterns in early childhood.

sourceRefs.citation: Cochrane Review. Group-based parent training programmes for improving emotional and behavioural adjustment in young children. CD003680.

evidenceItems.title: Limit-setting without repeated debate
evidenceItems.claim: Clear limits with minimal repeated negotiation can reduce reinforcement of refusal cycles.

sourceRefs.citation: Sege RD, Siegel BS. Effective Discipline to Raise Healthy Children. Pediatrics. 2018;142(6):e20183112.

evidenceItems.title: Public reset routine
evidenceItems.claim: In high-arousal public episodes, reducing stimulation and exiting the environment can be more effective than pressing task completion.

sourceRefs.citation: CDC. Essentials for Parenting Toddlers and Preschoolers.
sourceRefs.publisher: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

evidenceItems.title: Parent self-regulation before response
evidenceItems.claim: Parent stress and dysregulation are linked to poorer child emotional/behavioral outcomes; rapid caregiver reset is a protective tactic.

sourceRefs.citation: Meta-analysis of parental stress and child emotional/behavioral outcomes. PMID: 38636551.

evidenceItems.title: Single-step transition support
evidenceItems.claim: Transition support is stronger when parents provide one clear next action and reduce competing instructions.

sourceRefs.citation: CDC. Essentials for Parenting Toddlers and Preschoolers.
sourceRefs.publisher: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention

evidenceItems.title: Night events route to sleep execution
evidenceItems.claim: Bedtime and night-wake incidents are better handled by a dedicated sleep plan runner than generic daytime scripts.

sourceRefs.citation: Mindell JA, Kuhn B, Lewin DS, Meltzer LJ, Sadeh A. Behavioral treatment of bedtime problems and night wakings in infants and young children. Sleep. 2006;29(10):1263-1276.

evidenceItems.title: Outcome logging enables iterative adjustment
evidenceItems.claim: Routine recording of response and outcome supports consistent care adjustment over time.
